Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Exploratory Research in Creative Sketching for 3D Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: Sketching plays an important role in creative design. Early attempts at computer-aided sketching overlay a sketching interface on a CAD approach for 3D modeling. This approach has been successful in quickly communicating designs that have already been fully envisioned, but is problematic in early conceptual design. Fundamental in CAD is the requirement that there is always an underlying consistent 3D solid representation. Requiring a consistent 3D model is an impediment to early conceptual design. Geometric forms must be either constrained or generated automatically without the designer's input. In the early conceptual phase the designer needs the freedom to experiment with incomplete and possibly inconsistent views and details. Early work has shown that 3D design and analysis can be performed using only strokes attached to 2D planes placed in 3D space. This research extends the free-form paradigm by experimenting with additional sketch primitives and interactions. The base 3D stroke system will be used as a starting point. Techniques for selecting and displaying additional elements, such as images, 3D fragments and 2.5D surface representations will be added. The intellectual merit of the project is the change in the nature of CAD systems that better support conceptual design by incorporating sketches and concepts that can be placed on a 3D model without requiring that the model be made consistent, until the designer is ready to enforce consistency. The broader impact of the project is the development of sketching and CAD tools that are relevant to early concept and creative designers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
CAD (computer-aided design) systems have become essential for the development of complete documentation of structures to be built. CAD models developed late in the design process enable the precise specification of materials and their configuration. While useful for final designs, CAD systems require that the designer has already developed a mature vision of the final structure.

Recently there has been considerable interest in 3D modeling systems for earlier phases in the design of structures. Sketching programs that allow users to quickly define rough 3D definitions using specified gestures and commands have been developed. Current 3D sketching systems work by inferring a full 3D shape from simple strokes and gestures. While this allows rapid development, the system itself influences and limits the design by creating geometry that is not directly specified by the user.

The early stages of creative 3D design involve the development of multiple, possibly inconsistent or incomplete views of the new object or structure. Inconsistent views are impossible in current CAD and 3D sketching systems that share the property that at every step in the process there is an unambiguous 3D solid representing the design. As a result, the early stages of design are still performed on paper (or possibly 2D electronic sketches), where the final 3D form can remain ambiguous. Using paper or purely 2D electronic sketches in this phase limits the source material available to the user. Using paper or pure 2D also complicates the transition from early design to the 3D documentation stages. This work explored a new paradigm to support early conceptional architectural design that:

1. Avoids the problems of current computer-based systems that either impose unnecessary constraints on geometric form or automatically
create geometry.

2. Avoids limitations of paper or 2D sketches by providing access to a wide range of source material in digital form.

3. Avoids unnecessary work moving from early to final design stages by simple transition to final formal design specifications.

In this new paradigm, a designer builds a 3D collage of sketches, images and other graphical elements to form a design. As part of the work we also conducted user studies, which suggest the new approach has considerable promise.
